Package com.intellij.tasks

Class TaskRepository

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.intellij.tasks.TaskRepository
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    BaseRepository

    public abstract class TaskRepository
extends java.lang.Object
    Describes bug-tracking server. Do not forget to mark your implementation with Tag annotation to make it persistent.
    See Also:
    TaskRepositoryType, BaseRepository

      • NATIVE_SEARCH

        public static final int NATIVE_SEARCH
        Supporting this feature means that server implements some kind of issues filtering. It may be special query language like the one used in YouTrack or mere plain text search.

        If server supports this feature it MUST return tasks already filtered according to query parameter from getIssues(java.lang.String, int, long)} method, otherwise they will be filtered internally in TaskManager.getIssues(java.lang.String).

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

        public java.lang.String getUrl()
        URL of the server to be used in requests. For more human-readable name of repository (e.g. some imaginary URL containing name of selected project), that will be used in settings, use getPresentableName().

      • getIssues

        @Deprecated
public Task[] getIssues(java.lang.String query,
                        int max,
                        long since)
                 throws java.lang.Exception
        Deprecated. To be removed in IDEA 14. Use getIssues(String, int, int, boolean) instead.
        Get issues from the repository. If query is null, return issues should assigned to current user only. If server supports NATIVE_SEARCH feature, tasks returned MUST be filtered by specified query.
        Parameters:
        query - repository specific.
        max - maximum issues number to return
        since - last updated timestamp. If 0, all issues should be returned.
        Returns:
        found issues
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • getIssues

        public Task[] getIssues(java.lang.String query,
                        int offset,
                        int limit,
                        boolean withClosed)
                 throws java.lang.Exception
        Retrieve tasks from server using its own pagination capabilities and also filtering out closed issues.

        Previously used approach with filtering tasks on client side leads to non-filled up popup in "Open Task" action and, as result, missing tasks and various issues with caching.

        Parameters:
        query - arbitrary search query, possibly provided by user for search. It may utilize server specific query language.
        offset - index of the first issue to return
        limit - maximum number of issues returned by server in this request (or number of issues per page in some interpretations)
        withClosed - whether to include closed (e.g. fixed/resolved) issues to response
        Returns:
        found tasks
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

        public Task[] getIssues(java.lang.String query,

      • findTask

        public abstract Task findTask(java.lang.String id)
                       throws java.lang.Exception
        Parameters:
        id - task ID. Don't forget to define extractId(String), if your server uses not PROJECT-123 format for task IDs.
        Returns:
        found task or null otherwise. Basically you should return null on e.g. 404 error and throw exception with information about failure in other cases.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • extractId

        public abstract java.lang.String extractId(java.lang.String taskName)
        Attempts to extract server ID of the issue from the ID of local task (probably restored from project settings). It's perfectly legal to return the argument unchanged, e.g. YouTrack repository does so for ID of form IDEA-123.

        Basically this method works as filter that tells what repository local task belongs to. If it returns not null, this repository is attached to that local task and is used then to refresh it via findTask(String), update its state via setTaskState(Task, CustomTaskState), etc. Because the decision is based only on syntactic structure of ID, this approach works poorly in case of several repositories with similar issue IDs, e.g. JIRA and YouTrack, and so it's a subject of change in future.

        Parameters:
        taskName - ID of the task to check
        Returns:
        extracted ID of the issue or null if it doesn't look like issue ID of this tracker

      • setTaskState

        @Deprecated
public void setTaskState(Task task,
                         TaskState state)
                  throws java.lang.Exception
        Deprecated. Use setTaskState(Task, CustomTaskState) instead.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • setTaskState

        public void setTaskState(Task task,
                         CustomTaskState state)
                  throws java.lang.Exception
        Update state of the task on server. It's guaranteed that only issues returned by getAvailableTaskStates(Task) will be passed here.

        Don't forget to add STATE_UPDATING in getFeatures() and supported states in getAvailableTaskStates(Task).

        Parameters:
        task - issue to update
        state - new state of the issue
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        TaskRepositoryType.getPossibleTaskStates(), getFeatures()
